ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: all students should be required to take this course

With regards to assignments, I think a few more written assignments earlier in the semester might have helped solidify some of that early material in my mind.Also, given that so much of the exams were based on reading / interpreting graphs, it might have been helpful to spend more time focusing on breaking those down together in class. It sometimes seemed like we were trying to blow through as much material as possible, rather than doing deeper dives into what the professors considered the core concepts.

Question 1 - - I found the topic lecture readings to be very helpful and useful, but did not do any of the other reading after the first two or so weeks.Question 3 - - I found the carbon lake budget assignment frustrating and felt it didn't add much to my understanding of the class material. The modeling assignment was fun, but it didn't teach me much.Question 6 - - The class really slowed down in the second half of the semester.Question 7 - - I thought Professor Schmitz was fantastic - - engaging, exciting, and a great lecturer. I thought Professor Raymond was less engaging.
N/A

It would be better if this class was put into a management perspective earlier in the semester. I think students, including myself, would take more away from the class if it was taught through this lens.
The lectures, especially the ones that Os gave.
I really enjoyed the topic lectures, where we had the chance to think critically about scientific papers with the professors' guidance.
It gives students a general overview of system ecology and basic concepts in ecology with broad topic range.

The topic lectures were really fascinating. Also, having not studied ecology very much, I found the cell to leaf to landscape lectures fascinating. I also found Professor Schmitz' land ethic/conservation/footprint big ideas very compelling.
The topic lectures and the lectures in the latter half of the course after we had acquired a foundation and could better engaged with the subjects.
Learning how dynamic ecosystems are and that managing them is never so simple.

I really liked the emphasis on management. Os and Pete did a great job of contextualizing the information in terms of management.I liked the topic lectures, the modeling project (which might have been more useful closer to the beginning of the course), and learning about nutrient flows.

I didn't have any previous knowledge about ecology or ecosystems and the course was a great way to get introduced to the subject. The concepts we covered were interesting, relevant and practically oriented.
Os and Pete were fantastic professors, and between their lectures and their discussion of their own research, class was always really fun.

I thought Os and Pete did a good job lecturing and structuring the course. The modeling projects were at first daunting but overall a good experience and introduction to modeling. I really enjoyed the topic lectures and thought they were a nice alternative to regular discussion sections. Both guest lectures were good as well.
The class assignments and discussions were the most fruitful part of the class.
Os is a great teacher.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The enthusiasm of the professor.

Again, I sometimes felt overwhelmed by the amount of material we tried to get through in a given lecture -- I might have prepared less breadth and more depth to solidify my knowledge of the key ideas.
It may be helpful to add a field trip or lab sessions.

The two larger assignments could use some improvement. Things really improved when we moved into a smaller room, but before that the class atmosphere felt cold, distant, and impersonal. It was nice when the professors finally started using our names once we moved classrooms.

The integration of lectures and readings. The readings, aside from those for the topic lectures, were really not helpful to students without prior knowledge. It would be very helpful to introduce some sort of textbook into the first half of the course, particularly for students without an ecology background. The co-teaching could also be better integrated - felt a bit disjointed at times. The last project using R was also not well integrated into the course though it was a useful brief introduction to the tool.

I think that the pacing of the lectures sometimes felt like a sprint and since the concepts and information was complex it was hard to process all of the information at the same time that it was being delivered. For people without science backgrounds a lot of the information was over my head and it was hard to follow along.
The first few lectures should be overview or introduction to the subject - to cover basic ideas and terms for people who have never had ecology or environmental science classes.

I thought the first half of the course was very structured but then after the midterm it was a little confusing where everything fit and how the lectures tied together. Readings were also not assigned following the midterm and I think they should be in order to better understand the lecture material. With that said, I thought some of the readings in the first half of the semester were a little overwhelming as far as size/length.
We needed more guidance concerning the exams.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: very good, both from TA and instructor.
The TA was a gem -- always available and helpful. The professors were good at responding to questions.
All three were very helpful.

Ok. The TA was very available though it did not often seem that she knew exactly what the expectations of the professors were. The professors were accessible for the lake project in particular though they outside of the project context they could have encouraged us more to come to office hours and engage our own backgrounds in the course.

Very good.Pete's help for the mass balance project was invaluable and I wish that I had known about the quality of the data that he had before I spent so much time trying to find information on my own.

The TA was great! She was very helpful and answered any questions we asked. She was available for questions and overview sessions. She promptly answered e-mails and provided help with assignments. Overall, great job.
Both the instructors and the TA were available whenever I needed help. Tara was especially helpful answering questions by e-mail and hosting workshops.

Both Tara and Os/Pete were readily available and very welcoming. Pete was very helpful in helping me scope my lake carbon budget. Tara held office hours twice a week and made herself available by appointment for projects and exam prep-she was excellent. I never went to see Os but I know he was always available and willing/able to help as well.
The TA was very willing to meet up and help out.
The TA was amazing. Very responsive to student needs.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: My background is in ecology and this course really built on that background, I think it is very important for any environmental management program to have a good understanding of ecology.
I think of it as a good complement to other subjects I'm learning at FES, and an important foundational course for environmental management.
I am grateful for this background in ecology and want to know more.
Just for personal edification and literacy and not directly.
It complemented my background in biology well. It reinforced concepts I had learned in undergrad and it added ideas about management, which was novel for me.
It fits well into the overall program.I really appreciated that Pete talked about the ocean b/c it's largely ignored at FES.
The course gave me the introduction to the environmental science aspect of my program.

Before this course I had never taken any kind of ecology course and I felt that I needed to. Considering this was my first ecology course I was very pleased with the class and feel that it will serve as a strong foundation as I move forward here at FES with other ecology and science classes.
This course helped give me a science background to my environmental policy career field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because it was required and because I am interested in ecology.
I couldn't imagine graduating from FES without taking a core course on ecology -- it just seems so important to all environmental management decisions.
To get a background in ecology missing from my education so far.
Took it for literacy in ecology and knowledge of new directions in the field.
Because on the syllabus it had mentioned that evolution and biogeography would be covered.
I took it b/c it was suggested as a foundation.
To learn more about ecology, environmental science and ecosystems in general.
See above response.
To improve my understanding of scientific concepts.
An understanding for how carbon moves through the system is imperative for any environmental manager to know about.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
I'd say so -- I learned a lot and feel like I now have a sense of what the important questions are to ask, which is what I was hoping to get out of the class.
Yes.
Somewhat. Would have really loved a textbook.
Not quite. I think that having a basic textbook would have really helpedme learn more. BUT I do think that it was a valuable course.
Yes, but there was room for improvement.
Yes!
Yes, it did.
Slow start, but it got there.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes, although again, I would sacrifice some of the breadth of a little more depth at times.
I didn't know what to expect.
Somewhat. By the end I felt that I had pieced more of it together than I felt throughout.
Yes.
Yes.
More or less.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N/A
Helped a lot in preparing for exams

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take advantage of office hours for both the ta and the instructors and don't miss lectures.

I suggest you approach lectures through the lens of, "What practical environmental management questions might this help me answer some day?" That way, rather than seeming like dry concepts, the material comes alive a bit more, since you can then frame it with an eye towards future problem-solving.
Ask lots of questions and ask for better more instructive readings.
Though the work may seem mundane, the concepts are invaluable.
Get a lot of help from the TA.
Do the readings on time and ask questions if you don't understand anything.

I would take this course if you have never taken an ecology course. Os and Pete do a good job of covering all the bases and all the assignments are relevant and help you practically understanding the material. They also do a good job of tying everything back to management. Out of the three foundation courses I took this semester (Ecosystems and Landscapes, Physical Science, and Economics) this was the best.
Think of it through a management lens.
